attributes.title: [Ep365] Combinatorial Network Complexity
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about social feedback loops, scalability, and having better problems. Change creates change, and you wanna be thinking about those changes at least two layers deep. Otherwise you might wake up one day to copious amounts of minor splash damage or be left wondering how a tunnel has stymied your spaceship.

attributes.title: [Ep364] Seal Team One
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss difficulty tuning, balance, and noises. When you’re designing an experience, it’s important to keep in mind that it’s not just about your design – it’s about where your design meets each individual person. There’s no point in punishing the whole class because you’re afraid one person might cheat.

attributes.title: [Ep363] The Uncertainty Threshold
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about charlatans, circular definitions, and bunnywool. We revisit the idea of “You just gotta get in there.” If all you have are questions, getting in there is about figuring out some answers. HOW you do that looks different for different people for different goals. As it turns out, bunnywool isn’t one size fits all.
attributes.description:
This week, we talk about charlatans, circular definitions, and bunnywool. We revisit the idea of “You just gotta get in there.” If all you have are questions, getting in there is about figuring out some answers. HOW you do that looks different for different people for different goals. As it turns out, bunnywool isn’t one size fits all.

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • TimConceivable: In the US, there seems to heavy social stigma against sharing your pay rate with coworkers. What are your thoughts on this?
  • Fraser_: A recent episode detailed how you now think "bias towards action" is a disastrous philosophy that leads to bad code, wasted time, and tech debt. Does this mark the end of "you've just gotta get in there" as a studio work principle?

attributes.title: [Ep362] Outside the Bun
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss layers on layers on layers. It’s more useful to think of most things in terms of levels – of accessibility, of interaction, of knowledge. When you’re designing, design with those things in mind so that you can engage different people in different ways. That’s how you move beyond one note sweets to more satisfying desserts. (Though we still wouldn’t necessarily say no to the former.)

attributes.title: [Ep361] The Myth of Infinite Growth
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about DVD choices, inkblot movies, and shutting out the world. When you’re exploring a paradigm shift, a big part of that upfront investment is learning and creating new processes. Skills and concepts might be transferable, and the mechanical parts can be reproduced, but the thing that’s going to take time is developing context fluency. Remember though, if you don’t disrupt yourself, someone else is going to.

attributes.title: [Ep360] Imperfect Balance
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss secrets, knowledge mastery, and buffing pawns. Gameplay loops keep players engaged, but it’s all too easy to only think about mechanical loops. Providing various levels of engagement allows players to meet the game at different breadths and depths. And when things change, make sure they can cascade.

attributes.title: [Ep359] Oxi Clean of the Soul
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about hidden information, player choice, and doing less. Things are often different than what you think they’re going to be, and that’s okay! But if you mistake activity for progress, you’ve fallen into a guaranteed trap. The discovery of the things you shouldn’t do might just be the most valuable discovery of all.

attributes.title: [Ep358] Training Montage
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss more fan poking, feeding the beast, and reframing productivity. We had our quarterly review, and it was, as usual, illuminating! Productivity isn’t just about making stuff, and having more stuff isn’t always better. Sure, you could walk from NY to LA and feel like you’re making progress the entire time, but is that the best way to get to LA?

attributes.title: [Ep357] Metagame Playing Field
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about the nightmare of incentives, design arms race, and price. Despite what economists tell you, you can’t assume a can opener. Or a spherical cow for that matter. And certainly not a can opener that can open a spherical cow. Pricing signals much more than just the price to the consumer, and supply/demand curves are more shapes than you think.

attributes.title: [Ep356] The Paradox of Dave
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss opinion bludgeons, resource allocation, and quality time. By now, you know that we like to answer questions with questions. Context is important and you should always know why! In the long term, reducing cognitive load is the name of the game – everything else is a trap.

attributes.title: [Ep355] Invasive Social Nicety
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about beach funerals, clock shenanigans, and evaluating feedback. If you don’t understand why you’re doing something, you’re not engaging in best practices. In relationships, in the perception of time, and in understanding details. We’ve said it before and we’ll say it again: Context is EVERYTHING.

attributes.title: [Ep354] Normal Terrain
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss That One Game, invisible walls, and 30-dimensional space. When you’re trying to navigate unfamiliar territory, it’s useful to have a map. But you have to remember that the map is not the world; it’s a representation of multiple dimensions collapsed down to only two. Not only should you try to understand the thing you’re looking at, but you also need to understand HOW you’re looking at the thing.

attributes.title: [Ep353] Laying Siege
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about portable gaming, snow melt, and the low hanging fruit of web hacking. When the only problems you’re trying to solve are the ones that you created, it’s difficult to innovate. Your framework is stuck in what already exists, not what could be. There’s a difference between positioning yourself to win and positioning yourself to not lose.

attributes.title: [Ep352] Get Parched, Scrubgrass
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss time travel messaging, UX problems, and a lifestyle lens. Whatever you measure is what you optimize for, and like all decisions, that choice has consequences. If you don’t design for something, you might find yourself fighting against it instead. Whether you pay it now or later, the cost comes due. The goal is to be able to look at your future self and say “You’re welcome.”

attributes.title: [Ep351] A Slot Machine of Weather
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about nubless ears, the Andon Cord, and exploration. Productivity and efficiency are two separate concepts with a lot of overlap. What long term things are being sacrificed when the focus is solely on producing in the short term? What short term things are overlooked when it’s always the longview? There’s a cautionary tale in there somewhere about trees and planting them. Give it a moment; it’ll grow on ya.

attributes.formatted_summary: This week, we talk about nubless ears, the Andon Cord, and exploration. Productivity and efficiency are two separate concepts with a lot of overlap. What long term things are being sacrificed when the focus is solely on producing in the short term? What short term things are overlooked when it’s always the longview? There’s a cautionary tale in there somewhere about trees and planting them. Give it a moment; it’ll grow on ya.

attributes.title: [Ep350] Lightning Megaflash
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss snow folly, changing the game, and deliberate barriers. While we tend to put a lot of effort into eliminating obstacles, sometimes you want them in place. In those scenarios, as with the opposite, the barriers should be designed deliberately to serve the purpose you want them for. Otherwise, you’ll be jumping the worst kind of hurdles – arbitrary ones.

attributes.title: [Ep349] Sprinkles McIceCream
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: It’s a question episode this week, and we talk about illusory standardization, survivorship bias, and FOMO ad spend. Conformation may be necessary to make certain things easier, but is it possible to have conformation without harm? If you could name yourself whatever you wanted without fear of people being jerks, what would you name yourself? Would it still be Steve?

attributes.title: [Ep348] The Power of Dance
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss inertia, indices, and inflation. As we already know, measurements are, at best, approximations of the thing you actually want to measure. But that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t use a blunt instrument when that’s all you have. Sometimes an out-of-the-box solution still requires you to look in to the toolbox, ya know?

attributes.title: [Ep347] Hot Meals Here
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about seasons, toxic game dev industry bingo, and golden parachutes. The industry has gotten quite a shake-up with certain parties throwing unfathomable amounts of money around. What does this mean for game devs and consumers? Tune in for some lightly stunned speculation.

attributes.title: [Ep346] Blobs of Data
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss the space in space, beat frequencies of randomness, psychological overhead, and celebrate the launch of Crashlands+ onto Apple Arcade. We’ve been hard at work building THE FABRICATOR, so let’s talk about it – cold sweats, horrifying realizations, worry counters, and all! Punching into a new weight class requires a little bit of perspective.

attributes.title: [Ep345] Mobius Topology
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about inconspicuous consumption, selfism, and hierarchy. The people most aware of the problems that need to be solved are the ones that are confronted by those problems. Weird, right? The thing to remember is this: we’re all connected and we’re on the same side. Oh, and there’s a twist!

attributes.title: [Ep344] 2021 Retrospective
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss what we said was going to happen, what actually happened, and what might happen this year. 2021’s moniker was “Dunk on everyone” – what should 2022’s call to action be? We’ve got some ideas, but we want to hear your suggestions! Submit your taglines at https://podcast.bscotch.net

attributes.title: [Ep343] Midpoints
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about shoulds vs ises, mutual definitions, and sizing batches. It’s a listener question episode as we approach the end of the year! Integration is the hardest step in any process because that’s where (mis)communication happens. If you think things are perfect, you’re not looking closely enough. Remember, it’s not about the amount of time. It’s about the quality of that time.

attributes.title: [Ep342] Financial Hot Potato
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss rulesets, speculative hype bubbles, and the churn. New problems need new solutions, but we don’t really want to go in the other direction because, let’s face it, there are enough problems already without manufacturing more. Sometimes we’ll be lucky and sometimes we won’t. You just gotta hang in there, do your best, and survive.

attributes.title: [Ep341] January 2039
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about geographical time, SaaSes, and human fuel. There are solutions for every kind of problem out there. Some of them are better than others, but nothing off the shelf is going to be perfect for your needs. Introspect, explore the space. And as always, ask yourself what something is for. If the answer is solely “to support a capitalist dystopia,” maaaaaybe reconsider.

attributes.title: [Ep340] Hot Liquid Rocks
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss the camouflage technique, lie laughing, and terrorawe. So, numbers. Computers are good at numbers, but when you’re computing things at the scale of space, computers run out of them pretty quickly. And reinventing numbers is not exactly a weekend project, ya know? That’s before we even touch on the fact that the Earth is liquid and spacetime is mindbending.

attributes.title: [Ep339] Human Megaphone Hydra
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about enunciation bears, context management, and sleep-related soapboxes. There’s a difference between how you’re “supposed to” do things and what you should actually do. Because, as it turns out, everyone’s needs are different, and there’s no singular solution that will solve the same problem for each person. Since we never had a Lifehacks/Brainhacks class in school, guess we’ll have to get our protips from TikTok.

attributes.title: [Ep338] FENCEGATE
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss the hingey part of the hinge, sidegrading, and plaguemask carabiners. Everything is stupid and stupidly designed. Which might be horrifying to think about on the surface, but it means that nothing needs to be permanent. We can design things better. Otherwise, we’ll just be stuck with a gate that doesn’t open and a dumpster fire at our backs.

attributes.title: [Ep337] The Great Yeeting
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: This week, we talk about goblin engineering, gravitational pockets, and bottlenecks. Bottlenecks come in many shapes and sizes. Sometimes it’s a hotkey list. Sometimes it’s a one-dimensional key press. Sometimes it’s unidirectional vision. If bottlenecks are inevitable, where’s the best place for the bottleneck to be?

attributes.title: [Ep336] Tulip Craze
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: In this episode, we discuss bear-d feeders, money laundering schemes, and tooling. Tooling can solve a lot of problems, but it can’t really do anything about malice. That’s something you’ve got to figure out on your own. Have you considered putting it on the blockchain? After all, we truly live in the future.

attributes.formatted_summary: In this episode, we discuss bear-d feeders, money laundering schemes, and tooling. Tooling can solve a lot of problems, but it can’t really do anything about malice. That’s something you’ve got to figure out on your own. Have you considered putting it on the blockchain? After all, we truly live in the future.

attributes.title: [Ep335] Metalevel Complexity
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we talk about keeping your sneezes in, gamifying games, and educational frameworks. Not frameworks that are educational, but the frameworks through which we’re educated. The specifics don’t matter in the general case, except where they really, really do. Like they say, “I’ve got 99 problems, and pedagogy is most of them.” That’s how it goes, right?

attributes.title: [Ep334] Infinite List of Badness
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the great resignation, break points, and hooks and kickers. If someone doesn’t want the thing that you’re selling, instead of blaming that person, maybe you should reexamine your product and how you’re selling it. This goes for both game marketing and service industry jobs in late stage capitalism!

attributes.title: [Ep333] The Front Half of Satan
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! This week, we talk about Big Birdbath, the cube rule of food, and the intersection of fancy and impractical. You know what’s at the middle of that intersection? Kid gloves and shoes with absolutely no traction. I guess when you get rich enough, it doesn’t matter if you can walk across the floor of your own volition. That plus spherical burgers are further evidence that the elite are actually lizard people.

attributes.title: [Ep332] Winner Take All
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss invisible maps, convenience vs. security, and corporate fiefdoms. Spooky season is off to a great start with a good portion of the invisible network that runs our lives going down for several hours. I mean, the internet isn’t even a thing so much as it’s a thing between things. Although, when you’re made up of several loosely interconnected unstable parts, it’s amazing anything works at all.

attributes.title: [Ep331] Level 15 Dungeons
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Salutations, Shenanites! This week, we talk about 3n+1 sequences, perverse incentives, and competence tiers. You can’t build a healthy team when someone is making it all about them. Long-term success requires thinking collectively. But don’t let the failures of collective action prevent you from taking individual action. Your choices have impact. They still matter.

attributes.title: [Ep330] Boston Pizza Party
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Good day, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss hipsavers, pattern recognition, and what problems are actually interesting. Plus, we revisit our old standby “Design By Chaos” and examine whether or not it still holds up! People place a lot of value on the idea of hard work, but sometimes hard work is just hard. If it can be made easier, why not do it? There are infinite problems out there to solve. Leave the details to robots and books.

attributes.title: [Ep329] Pumpkin Spice Season Passes
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! This week, we talk about Air Bud situations, M&M revenue, and negative feedback loops. Work-life balance isn’t about time; it’s about having the ability to control how things interact and integrate. It’s not your fault that society is set up to burn you out. Remember, you’re a person. At some point, maybe you stopped doing the thing. That’s okay. Just start it up again when you can. You’re okay.

attributes.title: [Ep328] Spherical Tide Bringer
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss goose mace, the black mirror effect, and a paint-by-numbers player experience. When the whole world is artificial, how do you make things not feel contrived? Just like in real life, the answer has to do with reasons. As in, you should have them. If you’re going to teach a bear ballet, you better know why you’re doing it.

attributes.title: [Ep327] The Systems Checklist Trap
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Greetings, Shenanites! This week, we talk about spoons in the pot, car sheets, and emotional appeal. Rules aren’t there because they’re true; they’re there because they’re useful. Until they aren’t. Experience is learning when and where to break those rules. Still, all the VC money in the world won’t save you if you completely miss the point.

attributes.title: [Ep326] Intergenerational Ghost Warfare
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: What’s up, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss immortal cultures, kitchen dreams, and capturing visibility. Creating a moment is easier when everyone is anticipating your every move. It’s harder to capture eyeballs when no one’s around. When you’re analyzing the strategies of the rich and famous and wondering if they could work for you, it’s important to take a moment and ask yourself: are you Beyoncé?

attributes.title: [Ep325] Wrecking Plants
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Howdy, Shenanites! This week, we talk about structural supports, allocation of resources, and making meaning. Since we didn’t get to questions last week, this is purely a question episode! Well, except for a slight skeleton detour. Isn’t it weird how without bones or exoskeletons we’d be bags of goo? Just slurbing from one place to the next. Talk about road rash.

attributes.title: [Ep324] The Immersion Barrier
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Top of the morning (or afternoon, or evening) to ya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss runner’s gut, carnival games, and suspension of disbelief. It’s easy to fall into the trap of more information is always better, but that’s not necessarily true. Even if you could have all the details to start with, does that really make your experience better? After all, when you’re going from plan to execution, you can never know, in the absence of the executed plan, what you missed.

attributes.title: [Ep323] Jevens Nuance
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we talk about sure things, hot pipes, and what design by chaos really is. Our old friend the Jevens paradox pays us a visit, and it turns out that heuristic has some layers! Plus, listen in as we dive deep into our most contentious internal debate. Three brothers enter… and, well, three brother leave. Because conservation of mass.

attributes.title: [Ep322] Schrödinger's Urgency
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss a zombie way of life, a package full of people, and getting out of the work and working on the work. You can’t make people care about something important if they don’t understand what the experience is going to be. And you can’t explain to someone what the experience is because it’s experiential. ...Is lying required to get at a truth?
attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss a zombie way of life, a package full of people, and getting out of the work and working on the work. You can’t make people care about something important if they don’t understand what the experience is going to be. And you can’t explain to someone what the experience is because it’s experiential. ...Is lying required to get at a truth?

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • TigerSharkBassist: If you guys were to guess Flux's favorite type of music, what genre would it be?
  • allenmb: What're your thoughts on marketing hype vs facts? Expectations vs reality? What's the most outrageous claim y'all have made in life that ended up being 100% bullshit?

attributes.title: [Ep320] Non-ergonomically Close
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hail, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss good gestures, brain quirks, and arbitrary rules. The first step of any undertaking is visibility. You can’t think about the problems you’re trying to solve until you know what those problems are. If you don’t know what you’re trying to do, then you’re just doing things randomly. And like we’ve said before, it’s fine to flip randomly, but you better know what gradient you’re looking for.

attributes.title: [Ep319] The Human Experience
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: How’s it going, Shenanites? This week, we talk about the fractal universe, flippin’ bacteria, and urgent chaos. When you navigate by chemical receptors, the best you can do is to flip flop around until you find a nutrient gradient to pay attention to. Even a fancy flip is better than no flip when you’re trying to find new local maxima. Or maybe it isn’t. Everything is chaos.

attributes.title: [Ep318] Swirly Diagonals
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Good day, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the torch problem, confetti cards , and table scraps. We’ve talked about project creep and scope creep - now let’s talk about complexity creep! People expand the fill the spaces that they’re in, whether those spaces are physical or virtual. You know you’re outgrowing your current systems if you spend most of your time handing off work instead of actually doing the work. If you don’t filter the noise, then everything is chaos.

attributes.title: [Ep317] The Exploding Bloviation
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! This week, we talk about automagic, motion waste, and toothpaste mining. Sometimes when you use a robot that’s designed for someone else, you have to build another robot to undo some of the design. Better than doing it yourself probably. There are a lot of questions you should ask yourself when you’re investigating a new tool. Chief of these should be “but does it work though?”

attributes.title: [Ep316] Cloth Airplanes
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Good day, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss extraneous chats, what happens in the margins, and your house bones. It’s weird to think that we all live in a skeleton that we fill with personalized guts. And that, even though you and your life are changing constantly, that skeleton always stays the same. Well, at least until you decide to turn all your outlets right side up again, but who wants to go to all the effort to do that?

attributes.title: [Ep315] Probability Collapse
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! It’s a bit of a shorter episode this week because Sam got a new mic and it did NOT want to play nice. Even still, we talk about things that don’t exist, things that do exist, and CHAOS. There are infinite variables that influence what will happen, and you can’t predict them all. But once what happens happens, it’s already happened, so does it matter that you can't predict it? Talking about chaos is like talking about time travel -- confusing.

attributes.title: [Ep314] Human Paste
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Greetings, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss metajokes, how little people know, and bikeshedding. Sometimes figuring out the when for tackling a problem involves figuring out the why. You don’t wanna put Bandaids on poop piles. That solves nothing. Instead, consider putting on your fanciest boa and buying some avocados. We’re pretty sure that’ll bring us all one step closer to a better world.

attributes.title: [Ep313] Hermit Crab Life
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Salutations, Shenanites! This week, we talk about Victorian treatises, invisible structures, and how people aren’t robots. People are also different from each other - who knew? As it turns out, when you acknowledge those two facts, you can construct a conscientious, flexible environment that actually prioritizes a person’s experience. Let’s make the implicit explicit. There’s no reason to have the Inquisition design your office chair.

attributes.title: [Ep312] The Feature Jank Tradeoff
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Ahoy, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss dinosaur clipping, the purpose of ghosts, and perpetual impostor syndrome. Starting a creative project is like crossing a rickety rope bridge over a deep canyon -- if you think too much about the distance to the ground, you’ll never take the first step. And sometimes you need to prioritize the experience over technical perfection. After all, people will put up with a lot if they get to ride a triceratops.

attributes.title: [Ep311] Decoupling Nostalgia
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we’re all about listener questions! We talk about reality TV, fragile retention, and NFTs. Sometimes the hook is buried so deeply that it’s too hard to explain; you have to experience it in order to get enough context. Does that mean anything? Well. Anything can mean something if people decide it does.

attributes.title: [Ep310] Pin for Posterity
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss degrading magical experiences, the dentist backlog, and inelastic demand. Are rooms defined by what’s within them or what’s without? Do they need walls, and if so, how many? Are roofs required or optional? It turns out that sometimes the simplest concepts are actually quite complex, and complex concepts are even more so. Basically, if you find yourself spending two weeks wondering, “What IS a building?”, you might just be a game developer.

attributes.title: [Ep309] Gut Nerve KABLAM
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Good day, Shenanites! This week, we talk about why ketchup is in the sink, weird replay value, and the ratcheting cost of rewards. Early commitments might mean turning down future opportunities. But hey, if it makes sense for you to do, then do it. After all, if it’s good enough for physics, then it’s good enough for us.
attributes.description:

But hey, if it makes sense for you to do, then do it. After all, if it’s good enough for physics, then it’s good enough for us.

Podcast recs: This American Life, Radiolab, The Cut, Syntax.fm, Darknet Diaries Book rec: Phallacy by Emily Willingham

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Gearwip Toppybeep: Are there any podcasts that you listen to often and would recommend? Elyip Nipmoppa: Can you share the web dev podcasts and blogs you follow?

  • Xeflat Doorveer: How do you share/store game assets so everyone can access them? Do you use version control for any assets other than code?

attributes.formatted_summary: Good day, Shenanites! This week, we talk about why ketchup is in the sink, weird replay value, and the ratcheting cost of rewards. attributes.title: [Ep308] Tequila Crazy Straw
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss long weekends, ear bleeds, and managing noise. Everything that you do is about moving something from one place to another, whether you realize it or not. Recognizing the steps to the dance gets you that much closer to automation. It’s about cutting out the noise. Remember, the most powerful key at your disposal is the delete key!

attributes.title: [Ep307] Optimized Primes
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! This week, we talk about compounding actions, administrative creep, and the panopticon performance. The solution that works best on average is going to be suboptimal for everyone. Assuming you’re even solving the right problem. Knowing things is expensive. That’s why you should get robots to know things for you.

attributes.title: [Ep306] Jellybean Crisis
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the human scale, the pros of catastrophic errors, and Sam’s squibbly baby hands. The easy answers are always the wrong ones, especially if you aren’t asking the right questions. It’s all too likely you'll overlook the three boxes of kiwis right in front of your face when you’re out there looking for grapes.

attributes.title: [Ep305] The Beauty and the Terror
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Good day, Shenanites! This week, we talk about dad issues, honeymoon phases, and the other 300 things. It’s impossible to be aware of the things you’re not aware of. But once you become aware of them, it’s time to refactor. Sure, the structure is the culture, but the culture is also the structure. If you don’t ask why, you’re gonna have a bad time.

attributes.title: [Ep304] The Why of Water
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the unceremonious aftermath, interesting limitations, and 50% more money numbers. All the details are contingent, as ever, upon the bigger question of why. If you don’t even know the shape of the problem, how can you figure out the shape of the solution? Time for some reflection. Preferably while sitting at the edge of a flat blue sheet and looking out at the swamp waves.

attributes.title: [Ep303] Multi-tiered Engagement
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Greetings, Shenanites! This week, we talk about herd immunity, the beauty of well designed choice, and a game for aliens. The more you learn, the more you should iterate, coming ever closer to that elusive (and illusive) plane of enlightenment. Sometimes that means flipping your design approach completely. And sometimes that means ascending to n-dimensional space and trying to find your shadow.

attributes.title: [Ep302] Feline Staredown
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the black mirror effect, Adam’s waking nightmare, and a neck with legs. We’ve been making radio long enough to know what’s good, so let’s talk about visuals! Plus, Seth reveals what the biggest, coolest thing he’s worked on and made is. As it turns out, much like turtles, it’s QA all the way down.

attributes.title: [Ep301] Goal Fog
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Salutations, Shenanites! This week, we talk about rest, shattering the earth, and the most complicated part of developing a game. It’s not what you think. Or maybe it is. We can’t read your mind. But if you find yourself up against a mental wall, it’s probably time to reevaluate your questions.

attributes.title: [Ep300] Autoaudiodocumentary
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In our 300th episode, we discuss swimming in quarters, the imaginary track, and the target audience problem. Just because something is visible doesn’t mean it’s good or right. Just because something is invisible doesn’t mean it’s bad or wrong. As it turns out, everything is a design problem, and there’s always more nuance to figure out.

attributes.title: [Ep299] The Whiff to Nail Range
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! This week, we talk about sweeping smear frames, off-the-shelf solutions, and the student mindset. You’re just a robot doing robot stuff, and your subroutines are doing the best they can to work together. So if you do something cool, even if it leads to failure, celebrate it! Don’t discount your dope Mars landing progress!

attributes.title: [Ep298] Giraffe Dreams
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the absence of blinking, flat planes of blubber, and the controllers of yore. Sometimes innovation is just realizing that people have fingers and getting the correct hand count. The details might seem small, but they could mean the difference between a midlife crisis and a midlife opportunity. So go ahead and grab some matcha with Bscotcha and listen in!

attributes.title: [Ep297] A Believable Lie
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about less random randomness, floors and ceilings, and proper beverage production. Plans aren’t plans so much as they’re educated guesses. Adherence runs counter to adaptation, and it’s important to know when and where to switch modes. What we’re saying is, get those pillars!

attributes.title: [Ep296] The Short Squeeze
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the glockenspiel of the financial trade, robot price wars, and the golden rule of financial investments. Our human brains are wired to chase novelty, but boring stability is the real end game. That’s why you need to create your own chaos. Say, by making a game in a weekend using skills you don’t have. It’s 2021 -- let’s go dunk poorly!

attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss face down positioning, quiet future knives, and surprise presentations. Do you ever think about how we’re mostly made of bacteria and weird blood? And how your skin can, like, taste things? No? Well, you’re thinking about it now.

attributes.title: [Ep293] Psychological Arms Race
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about clearing techdebt, our robot overlords, and a billboard owners. For this ep, we’re light on the news and go to town a few questions. Like break strategies. Sometimes you need to take a break from work because your bladder demands it. You just have to decide if it’s a six mug break or a two mug break.

attributes.title: [Ep292] Orbital Strike Dunk
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Happy New Year, Shenanites! In the first episode of 2021, we discuss doll caverns, deep truths, and conscious memorization. This year is all about the dunks, and the first step is gathering intel. Who’s the fastest runner in your workplace? Which of your colleagues can do a backflip? Do you even know? You gotta have an audience to make a dunk. I mean, if a tree dunks in a forest, did it even dunk at all?

attributes.title: [Ep291] Finite Checkpoints
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Season’s greetings, Shenanites! This week, we talk about chapter ends, an elaborate system of mirrors, and total death traps. It’s the last episode of 2020, so we break down our year in review. What was the timeline? What was our experience? Did we learn any lessons? And as for the future? It’s time for getting stuff done with bombastic butterfly dunks.

attributes.title: [Ep290] A Firehose of Data
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans

attributes.title: [Ep289] Fruit Stickers
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about boring adventures, picking up soda bottles, and doing things. As in, how do? It’s tempting to look for a system or secret that’s the answer to EVERYTHING, but it turns out that sometimes things are just hard. Strategies work until they don’t, and then you find a new one! Just make sure you don’t use up all your toughness on things like toothaches. That’s what Tylenol is for.

attributes.title: [Ep288] Liquid Bug Phase
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss tool inertia, diluting the particulate poo, and math. We tried to take more time for questions this week and ended up airing some grievances. But that’s what happens when you have highly specific pet peeves: one minute you’re talking about slippers, and the next you’re ranting about water slapping nonsense. Seems about par for the course.

attributes.title: [Ep287] False Gates
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! We’re taking a break from our break in order to discuss holiday creep creep (we said what we said), ground warts, and console tribalism. By the time you hear this episode, we’ll be at least half way through the second of two superspreader capitalism event weeks! Stay safe, mask up, and remember, you can always work remotely from Barbados.

attributes.title: [Ep286] Feral Obi-Wan
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about rad cats, content glut, and the indiepocalypse. It’s all about weathering the storm long enough to weatherproof your boat. Although at some point, your boat is so weatherproofed that you’ve reached the threshold of diminishing returns. As with everything, survival is key.

attributes.title: [Ep285] Druid Bias
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss information diets, radioactive piles of poop, and asynchronous mentorship. All data is spun, but whether you get gold or pasta at the end is unpredictable. Plus, context changes all the time, so maybe someday you’ll WANT spaghetti consequences. Turns out, everything is hard, and it’s just a bunch of triangles anyway, each following a different path.
attributes.description:
Heya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss information diets, radioactive piles of poop, and asynchronous mentorship. All data is spun, but whether you get gold or pasta at the end is unpredictable. Plus, context changes all the time, so maybe someday you’ll WANT spaghetti consequences. Turns out, everything is hard, and it’s just a bunch of triangles anyway, each following a different path.

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Woland77: Does the explosive post-end-of-support popularity of Among Us have any meaningful lessons for developers about maintaining their old games, or is it just a statistical outlier with no real lessons for anyone?
  • Flyhoppie Axerompa: Are there any tools you use or really anything you do that you believe listeners shouldn't try to emulate?

attributes.title: [Ep284] The Bread-Cake Gradient
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we talk about gummi bear jackets, trash tier debt, and triangular muffins. In reality TV, entertainment trumps function every single time, so it is imperative that we save other baked goods from going the way of the cupcake. Do you really want to live in a world where twelve pounds of frosting are piled on every bread-thing you eat? Which side of the donut wars will you be on?
attributes.description:
Hi, Shenanites! This week, we talk about gummi bear jackets, trash tier debt, and triangular muffins. In reality TV, entertainment trumps function every single time, so it is imperative that we save other baked goods from going the way of the cupcake. Do you really want to live in a world where twelve pounds of frosting are piled on every bread-thing you eat? Which side of the donut wars will you be on?

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Levelheaded: How does the revenue system work for different platform partnerships?
  • Beekie Boppaboop: What would be the best thing to find in the middle of the cupcake? The worst?
  • Flyhoppie Axerompa: What office chairs do you guys use?

attributes.title: [Ep283] Monkey Law
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss happy lights, the weird disconnect, and accurate genre classifications. Do you ever think about how weird it is that we’re just a bunch of monkeys that chose to put on clothes and live in a world with rules that are artificially constructed by other monkeys based on the nonsense they believe? Sometimes when we’re in the grind, our minds wander. See these termites? These are money now.

attributes.title: [Ep282] Skeleton Gateways
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! This week, we talk about the three stages of animation, the spectrum of engagement, and a weird trifecta of totally oppositional forces. We also talk about cake. Like a lot. Whether you can have it or eat it or both. There are a lot of great outcomes when cake is involved. And skeletons! The easiest way to give permission to grown-ups to have fun is to add a skeleton. And that, friends, is what Halloween is all about.

attributes.title: [Ep281] Money Value
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Salutations, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss real time learning curves, a big dumb week, and the only valuable patents. When you talk about exclusives, you never really talk about who is excluded. For example, Sam is the exclusive recipient of THE LOTS this year, and that means no M&Ms for anyone else. TL;DR Capitalism is bad.

attributes.title: [Ep280] Big Brain Quarter
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about predeciding, the naming problem, and ending conversations. Our quarterly review revealed that we haven’t done enough thinking about thinking about things because doing things is often a lot easier. Until suddenly it isn’t. Every time a thing is hard, ask yourself, “Does it have to be?” Frankly, we could all use a burrito.
attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about predeciding, the naming problem, and ending conversations. Our quarterly review revealed that we haven’t done enough thinking about thinking about things because doing things is often a lot easier. Until suddenly it isn’t. Every time a thing is hard, ask yourself, “Does it have to be?” Frankly, we could all use a burrito.

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • challosis: What are the Game Maker project files called for all of your past games?
  • Grintrim Gappaquip: I have a few questions about GR18's design: Is the display on his face crt, hologram, lcd or led? Were all models or GR18 powered by burritos? If I was to attempt to open up my GR18 and tinker around would it void my warranty?

attributes.formatted_summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about predeciding, the naming problem, and ending conversations. Our quarterly review revealed that we haven’t done enough thinking about thinking about things because doing things is often a lot easier. Until suddenly it isn’t. Every time a thing is hard, ask yourself, “Does it have to be?” Frankly, we could all use a burrito.

attributes.title: [Ep279] Cupcakes and Mugs
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the good kind of spooky, tooling states, and our deficiencies. But how are you supposed to know how the things you’re taught in high school apply to a thing you don’t know you want to do as a job? Try saying that three times fast. Also, try saying the word “weaning.” It’s a dumb word the more you say it. Weaning. Weeeeaaannning. You’ll see.

attributes.title: [Ep278] Twumbly Beef
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Greetings, Shenanites! This week, we talk about sandwich butts, the right pants website, and our time traveling future selves. If you’re ten percent chocolate, are you a touch dead? Is it worse to accept a little more stress or a little more poison? Remember, comfort zones aren’t risk free. So be wary of false dichotomies when you’re workshopping your new YouTube channel.

attributes.title: [Ep277] The New Vaping
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss the sleep stuporous state, quarantine wardrobes, and bot wars. Do you ever think about how bugs are just cute litter butter packets wrapped in a shell? And how many goldfish crackers are calorically equivalent to a butterfly? How big or how small things are is wild. It’s a small pleasure to be able to insulate the people you love from some of the nonsense, but it’s also a pleasure to share some of it. So grab a buddy, grab your coffee, and let’s get nonsensical!

attributes.title: [Ep276] The Beautiful Cube
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! This week, we talk about tiny poisonous sticks, determinism, and how stuff can be two things. Measurements are trickier than they appear. I mean, we can’t even measure things well enough to know the state of something IN THIS VERY MOMENT. You probably don’t even know what’s behind you RIGHT NOW. Don’t look! It’s for the best.

attributes.title: [Ep275] Memory Density
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss bounty hunting, comfort games, and chaos engines. Sometimes you need to live life precariously in order to feel truly alive. So, don’t shy away from danger! Balance that scone box on your drink! Balance your peanut butter-y fork on that jar of peanut butter! Balance your meat suit on that wobbly deck railing! Hm… there seems to be some kind of theme here.

attributes.title: [Ep274] Unhinged Arcade
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about high complexity gimmicks, bad reviews, and how to measure a table. As adults, we need to be better about scheduling time in our days for being responsibly irresponsible. Everything is part of the process, even if you aren’t sure how yet. That’s why you need to stay mentally hungry, even if your belly is full of pizza.

attributes.title: [Ep273] Toothbrush Hijacking
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi again, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss brain soup, perfect sticks, and house magicians. Things that are simple aren’t always easy. Sometimes you need the right tools for the job, and sometimes it’s better to leave it to the professionals. Unless you do such a bad job that no professional will come near it. One day, deck… One day.

attributes.title: [Ep272] Horizontal Tornado
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! This week, we talk about fancy footwork, epic power imbalances, and socially distant greetings. When it’s too dangerous to hug people, how do you lock-in your greeting and introduce chaos, the universal social lubricant? If you try one of our ideas, let us know how it goes! Plus, as a bonus, we reveal what the www in your url really stands for.

attributes.title: [Ep271] Fizzy Pickles
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans

attributes.title: [Ep270] Hypercondensed Slapstick
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we talk about elaborate trap construction, tech curmudgeons, and the business equivalent of peanut butter shorts. The problems you needed to solve yesterday aren’t always the same as the problems you need to solve today. You’re definitely going to do it wrong, but there are ways to do it less wrong. Step one, get an endless supply of tiny spoons.

attributes.title: [Ep269] Laser Sausage

attributes.title: [Ep268] Sconegate
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about muscley butterflies, small batch cat introductions, and a fractal universe. The most important part of a biased random walk is the bias. As long as you know vaguely where you’re going, a wildly circuitous route can still get you there. Just don’t look too deep -- those triangle muffins will look right back.

attributes.title: [Ep267] Spectrum of Commitment
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we discuss evolving PCs, load obfuscation, and daily acceleration. Why do we have so many hard drives? Are woodchucking and swoopadooping results mostly based on willpower? If we can’t make a good fake strawberry taste, how can electricity? Better read the whole paper to find out.

attributes.formatted_summary: Hi, Shenanites! This week, we discuss evolving PCs, load obfuscation, and daily acceleration. Why do we have so many hard drives? Are woodchucking and swoopadooping results mostly based on willpower? If we can’t make a good fake strawberry taste, how can electricity? Better read the whole paper to find out.

attributes.title: [Ep266] Techdebt Burndown Rodeo Circus
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about the three body problem of cats, aggressive obfuscation, and the problem with a byte. We’ve got so much life advice packed into this one episode, you don’t even know! Literally. Because there are five minutes that are lost to time, and those were the most important five minutes of all. Oh well. Here’s a nugget anyway: Be kind to your future self, because you are your greatest collaborator.

attributes.title: [Ep265] Cookie Bandolier
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we discuss real human experiences, the tyranny of social contracts, and, yet again, how economists are wrong. That’s just a well that never runs dry. It is possible to be both cynical about humanity and also awed by human ingenuity and creativity. What can we say? It’s complicated. But hey, at least there aren’t any murderhornets. ...right?

attributes.title: [Ep264] Technical Caveman
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about postmortems, focused jamming, and the entubening. Diversifying your experience at the start lets you go faster later on. A body in motion stays in motion. A body stuck in one position for twelve hours a day probably atrophies. Or something. Physics, ya know?

attributes.title: [Ep262] Black Lives Matter
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites. This week’s podcast is different than our usual shenanigans. Staying silent in the face of injustice is an endorsement of the status quo, so in this episode we’re going to talk about implicit bias, working towards being antiracist, and what you can do to help. If you’re into the games we make, have enjoyed our previous podcast episodes, or think you like us as people, stay here with us. Listen to this whole episode.
attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites. This week’s podcast is different than our usual shenanigans. Staying silent in the face of injustice is an endorsement of the status quo, so in this episode we’re going to talk about implicit bias, working towards being antiracist, and what you can do to help. If you’re into the games we make, have enjoyed our previous podcast episodes, or think you like us as people, stay here with us. Listen to this whole episode.

Book recommendations:

  • So You Want to Talk about Race, Ijeoma Oluo
  • White Fragility, Robin DiAngelo
  • Jen also recommends: How to Be an Antiracist, Ibram X. Kendi

Additional resources can be found here: https://tinyurl.com/antiracistresourceguide

Donate to Black Lives Matter here: https://bit.ly/2A7T6oG

attributes.title: [Ep261] Positive Swearing
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about inflection points, poking the fan, and warning ambivalence. The most valuable thing you can do is discover that you don’t need to do something. And the worst way to teach something is to not teach it at all. Those are just two of the wiznugs from this week’s flavor packed ep! So grab your coffee and get to listening!

attributes.title: [Ep260] Aphid Warfare
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Howdy, Shenanites! This week, we discuss murder ecosystems, barometers for demand, and the worst thing about pizza. Can your every day carry change what “home” means? How are you supposed to hold a reverse knife? Since you can’t guarantee 100% satisfaction, just remember that the perpetual feeling of underdelivering is the result of receiving the highest praise from another human person. Okay, that last bit might not have been as amusing, but listen to all the other bon mots we make with our bouches!

attributes.title: [Ep258] Random Social Exclamation
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! This week, we discuss depressurization, con generators, and a cheesy arms race. You know, life is just an endless series of trying to find things to do. That’s why you gotta be combinatorially interactive and strike a balance between local maxima and marginal benefits. Or something. Grab a mug, fill it with drinkable liquid, and let’s consult the numbers!

attributes.title: [Ep256] A Bespoke Physics Experience
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Halloo, Shenanites! This week, we discuss the in-between space, the cruelest barb, and pillars. You need them to hold things up sometimes. The launch of Levelhead is IMMINENT, and it’s coming out HOT, so check the batteries in your smoke alarms and get your conspiracy theories in order. Levelhead will be hitting your favorite storefronts TOMORROW, APRIL 30th! Links at https://levelhead.io .
attributes.description:
Halloo, Shenanites! This week, we discuss the in-between space, the cruelest barb, and pillars. You need them to hold things up sometimes. The launch of Levelhead is IMMINENT, and it’s coming out HOT, so check the batteries in your smoke alarms and get your conspiracy theories in order. Levelhead will be hitting your favorite storefronts TOMORROW, APRIL 30th! Links at https://levelhead.io .

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Mopait Flatunk: Twice now, just as I've started up Levelhead, my wife has set off the smoke alarms in the house and forced me jump off the computer to save the family, or at least to get the dog to quit howling. Is this a conspiracy? Is she just trying to get me away so she can play the game? Should I just not let her cook anymore? Or is Levelhead just that SMOKE'N?!?!?!?
  • Fraser_: How did you decide on Thursday, April 30th to launch Levelhead?
  • Flyhoppie Axerompa: Sam, a long time ago you spoke about how at the end of Crashlands development you had to pull back on your art skills a bit to make sure the game looks consistent. Did you find yourself doing the same thing for LevelHead?
  • challosis: Do you have design pillars that you followed for Levelhead?

attributes.title: [Ep253] TP Bamboozlement
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about sports humans, the bidet contingent, and getting on the Ferris wheel. The Levelhead launch is now less than four weeks away, and the gold build is done! Who knew that three bug fixes and changing a zero to a one would be so emotional. When you break through a milestone, there’s often a goal vacuum left behind. We should probably fill it with more than peanut butter whisky and mouthwash...
attributes.description:
Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about sports humans, the bidet contingent, and getting on the Ferris wheel. The Levelhead launch is now less than four weeks away, and the gold build is done! Who knew that three bug fixes and changing a zero to a one would be so emotional. When you break through a milestone, there’s often a goal vacuum left behind. We should probably fill it with more than peanut butter whisky and mouthwash...

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Flyhoppie Axerompa: If you gave your wives full creative control over your next game project, but were still in charge of the technical execution of creating that game, what would that project look like?
  • Butterscotch Atheist: Thoughts on looking at other game’s game reviews and learning from their mistakes?
  • TimConceivable: ADAM! With the TP shortage of 2020, are you going to finally hook up that bidet?
  • cprice: What are your views on post-launch business models in indie games?
  • Vuvu987: Seth, you went on a quest for gains a few episodes ago. Do you have any tips for a quest for loss?
  • Underscrum Rompyyerblee: You are each stuck on different islands for the rest of your lives and you can only have one book, one alcoholic beverage, and play one video game. What do you choose?

attributes.title: [Ep252] Banshee Sprints
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hail and well met, Shenanites! Welcome back to your weekly dose of something approximating comedy! attributes.title: [Ep251] Orchestra of Effort
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about living on a spaceship, hotel WODs, and void houses. Working from home means that all times are peak times. A pandemic is sweeping the world, and we’re all in this together -- do what you can to help! It’s about attitude. And excellent distance socializing.
attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about living on a spaceship, hotel WODs, and void houses. Working from home means that all times are peak times. A pandemic is sweeping the world, and we’re all in this together -- do what you can to help! It’s about attitude. And excellent distance socializing.

(Speaking of, our audio is different in this episode because we have to be together apart. It’ll probably continue to be different in future eps. Just a heads up!)

Semantics note: We used the term “quarantine” to talk about the stay-at-home sitch going on, but that’s not quite right. For your ref, quarantine means that a person has been exposed, isolation means that the person is sick, and social distancing is what the rest of us should do in order to help (6 feet! Hand sanitizer! Stay home!). Whew! Words, ya know?

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Beekie Boppaboop: The next prime podcast is 251, just so you know. It is also an Einstein Prime and a Sophie Germain Prime and a Chen Prime.
  • Underscrum Rompyyerblee: If you had a World of Warcraft-like mount in real life, which would each of you choose?
  • Woland77: I have noticed that a lot of the games going up for free on the Epic Store are the base version of games with DLC or different versions. Is this the new "demo?" What do you think about this development in the economy of games?

attributes.title: [Ep250] Tumbleweed Cough
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! This week, we discuss idiot testing, the accidental nature of procrastination, and what brains are bad at. Games have to respect the lassoo if they’re going to reach escape velocity. Which is to say, the news you’ve all been waiting for is finally here...
attributes.description:
Hiya, Shenanites! This week, we discuss idiot testing, the accidental nature of procrastination, and what brains are bad at. Games have to respect the lassoo if they’re going to reach escape velocity. Which is to say, the news you’ve all been waiting for is finally here...

Levelhead is launching on APRIL 30th! To so many platforms, your head might explode. But don’t let it -- you’ll need that noggin for building, sharing, and playing all those sweet, sweet levels.

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Beekie Boppaboop: How can you tell the difference between taking a break and procrastination?
  • smellyplatypus: Do you guys have any tips for someone looking to optimize their early life in order to make a good transition into work and business?
  • peabnuts123: Do you still have a so-called “10% rule”?

attributes.title: [Ep249] The Curse of Knowledge
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Greetings, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about blame nets, the strongest cereal, and Norman doors. Once you have your ducks in a column and your crabs in a row, you can turtle up and just start poking people. At base, learning, teaching, and, really, all forms of communication are about figuring out assumptions. Once you do that, the world is your truffle!

attributes.title: [Ep248] Fingercones
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey hey, Shenanites! This week, we discuss reality show pitches, cheap hobbies, and minimalist hyper casual garbage. Do you know who else believed in rapid prototyping and small batch delivery? Hint: airplanes were involved. Which is to say, history is more than just a recounting of wars. Sometimes it’s running a marathon in a suit.

attributes.title: [Ep247] Puckphone Bottleneck
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about those tricksy menisci, the complexity of screenshots, and elbow rubbing. attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about those tricksy menisci, the complexity of screenshots, and elbow rubbing. Plus a whole grab bag of questions, ranging from breakfast desserts to color wheels. Whenever you’re feeling down, just remember this: A list isn’t defined by what’s in it; it’s defined by what it can do.

If you want to check out Jen’s podcast Docs Watch, go to https://docswatchpod.com! Or find it on Apple (https://apple.co/381yiLc) or wherever you get your podcasts!

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • The DeadEarthMan: Since moving into vegetarianism, how much has your consumption of eggs increased to maintain protein intake for MUSCLE MASS!?
  • Woland77: Sam, do you still eat eggs? If not, what did you replace them with in your protein-powered workout diet?
  • Woland77: Is math real?
  • challosis: What is your second favorite breakfast cereal?
  • Jablong Funkogourdie: What book would you provide to someone random?
  • Butterscotch Atheist: What is the bscotch employee training like? Is it five hours of package delivery guides?
  • drhayes: Is there a particular palette that you try to stick to? Particular levels of brightness or saturation? Do you sketch on paper first, or is it Inkscape all the way?
  • Beekie Boppaboop: How do you pick colors for new things in levelhead so everything looks nice together?
  • divo: What can I do to make sure I show up in everyone's inbox?

attributes.title: [Ep245] Ball and Socket
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Heya, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about distributing polish points, the sine wave of life, and Seth’s sports beeves. With games like Faceball and Killball, it’s amazing anyone makes it out of childhood with their teeth intact. If you don’t want to engage in shin-to-shin or ball-on-base combat, maybe try swimming instead. At least the pool doesn’t bellyflop you -- YOU bellyflop IT.

attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we talk about the worst word, cocooning, and “just in time” refactoring. How do you eat spaghetti? Definitely not by lining each noodle up in a row. What are you trying to build, a raft? To sail the sea of red sauce? While navigating around meatballs? Hm. Now we’re hungry.

attributes.title: [Ep242] Planck Minutes
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! This week, we discuss sorting by bigness, fractal loose ends, and your 600 senses. Every moment of existence is split into infinity, so there’s always the chance that one of the versions of you can accurately measure volumes. I mean, how else would they have managed to fit forty-five miles of nerves in your body?

attributes.title: [Ep241] Human Spectra
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: How’s it going, Shenanites? In this episode, we talk about Sisyphian tasks, relationship FOMO, and reasonable metrics. When you’re trying to measure the truth and all you have are proxies, you have to ask yourself: what truth do you actually care about? Probably the one with the euphonium and the flaming coconuts.
attributes.description:
How’s it going, Shenanites? In this episode, we talk about Sisyphian tasks, relationship FOMO, and reasonable metrics. When you’re trying to measure the truth and all you have are proxies, you have to ask yourself: what truth do you actually care about? Probably the one with the euphonium and the flaming coconuts.

Note: Sam says ADD, but that term isn’t used any longer. The current terminology is ADHD.

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Mimmabip Gourkee: Seth talks about the WoW problem, where the more streamlined the game gets, the harder it is to connect with people. Do you guys see this problem happening in real life and do you have any experiences?
  • Gabe: What talent/ability do each of you have that might surprise us?
  • Alsastre: How many lines of code does Level Head consist of? What do you use for VCS? Dark or light mode?

attributes.title: [Ep237] The Molten Ice Company
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hiya, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss questing for strains, the impracticality spectrum, and blockchain nickels. What if your grammar lettuce is wilted? What if it’s dark upstairs? What if a squirrel gets stuck in your vacuum wall? Who knows. Our brains only like to pose the questions, not go the extra answer. SEGUE. You know what they say about long hands? Ya need long pens.

attributes.description:

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • Wigglyhonk Quickpie: Are there any other game developer podcasts out there like yours that you all listen to?

attributes.title: [Ep235] Question Blitz Pt 2: The Poptarts to Pain Ratio
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi again, Shenanites! Welcome to part two of our question blitz! It’s blitzier this time. In this episode, we drink moonshine and talk about sexy vampires, pointy pointing pointers, and unicycling badly. You gotta put on your noise canceling headphones and develop practice discipline. Otherwise that spaghetti code is just gonna slap you in the face. Which would YOU rather?

attributes.title: [Ep234] Question Blitz Pt 1: The Non-Blitzy Part
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanies! If you’ve been following along, you know that the studio is going to be thrown into chaos over the next couple weeks. But we couldn’t leave your coffee in the lurch without butterscotch, so we pre-corded some shenanigans for you! In this episode, we talk about high sneeze potency, vegetarian radiation, and opinionated tools. Here’s the long and short of it: Remain curious and open to new things. Think about the light you’re reflecting out into the world. Oh, and get vaccinated, if you can.

attributes.title: [Ep232] Defiance Oriented
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Ahoy, Shenanites! In this episode (which is actually 232, so... ya know), we discuss hot reloads, the meaning of meat, and A BIG NEWS ALERT. Sometimes you can find your joy in making shit games, and sometimes you can find it in head sweater tubes. Either way, the important thing is the joy.
attributes.description:
Ahoy, Shenanites! In this episode (which is actually 232, so... ya know), we discuss hot reloads, the meaning of meat, and A BIG NEWS ALERT. Sometimes you can find your joy in making shit games, and sometimes you can find it in head sweater tubes. Either way, the important thing is the joy.

Send us AS MANY (good) QUESTIONS AS YOU CAN. Because we’re going to be recording DOUBLE, and we need your ideas! Also, we can all agree that 2019 is a garbage year, right? Now’s the time to think about what to name 2020! Can it top twenty-plenty? If so, let us know! Go to https://podcast.bscotch.net to submit either or both. Or, if you’re running dry on ideas, vote for your favorite questions and suggestions!

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • BscotchChristine: We don't hear enough about the Bscotch ladies! How did you meet your wives? What is something about them we don't know? ----- Diana’s IG: dianazeng_ (https://bit.ly/2NzmHLo) ----- Jen’s Twitter and IG: jcalyst (https://bit.ly/2p7i4yL) ----- Sampada’s IG: sampada6361 (https://bit.ly/2O4Feyn)
  • DwarvenJester: So now that Seth is an experimental vegetarian, does he still celebrate MeatPieceWeen? Does it become PotatoSliceWeen instead?
  • challosis: Are there any jam/trash/tiny/flash games that you sometimes still go back to?
  • Butterscotch Atheist: Do indie developers avoid the polish stage to save time, or is it because of the AAA studios' relatively massive budget?
  • Gua: Do you believe that for an average indie game developer gameplay innovation usually pays off, or does it more often lead to a complete financial failure? Is it better to make genre games if one does want to continue making indie games?

attributes.title: [Ep228] One Hundred Taurs
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: What’s up, Shenanites! This week, we talk about the ongoing saga of 2019, weaponizing tools, and crusts full of beeeees. How many exposure bucks does being at the top cost you? Are you blinded by your creative high? In the aggregate, the typical response is the reality -- just like pineapple on pizza.
attributes.description:

attributes.title: [Ep225] LIVE from Shenanicon 2019!
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey there, Shenanites! Your fellow Bscotcheroonies asked, and we answered LIVE at Shenanicon 2019! In this episode, we discuss the paradox of productivity tools, algorithmic curation, and burning the boats. We get pretty existential, but then, when do we not? Here’s a pro tip: as cool as it sounds, don’t name your kid Scam Likely.
attributes.description:
Hey there, Shenanites! Your fellow Bscotcheroonies asked, and we answered LIVE at Shenanicon 2019! In this episode, we discuss the paradox of productivity tools, algorithmic curation, and burning the boats. We get pretty existential, but then, when do we not? Here’s a pro tip: as cool as it sounds, don’t name your kid Scam Likely.

Thanks to everyone who came out to the second Shenanicon!

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • AngryMuffin: What was it like going back to Scuffle Buddies after working on Levelhead for so long? How hard was it to get it playable for the convention?
  • Cprice: If you could have one Levelhead power up in real life, which would it be?
  • Ben C: Are there any productivity tools that you've tried but decided against using in the long run?
  • The_Rumpus: If you had the time/the want, what would be the SECOND Butterscotch Shenanigans podcast?
  • QuantumAnomaly: Do you find it difficult to come up with something (like say, a podcast question) when you feel like you're being put on the spot, or do you operate better under pressure?
  • Adam M: Google announced Play Pass this week, stating that developers will be paid according to an algorithm that incorporates time spent in their app with unknown factors to determine which titles "bring the highest user value." How do you think this will change the mobile game ecosystem?
  • Ps7cho: What "old person" things do yall do?
  • Mr. Ward: How important do you think staying on brand as a game studio is? If you are known for a certain genre or style of game, how would you transition to trying something else?
  • Alex T: What is the thing you found most surprising and/or unexpected in any stage of development, either positive or negative?
  • lexzap: You can only own one gaming device: mobile phone, Switch, Playstation, or Xbox. Which one would you choose and why?

To stay up to date with all of our buttery goodness subscribe to the podcast on Apple podcasts (apple.co/1LxNEnk) or wherever you get your audio goodness. attributes.title: [Ep224] The Goat Square-Up
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss infinite work, the age of curation, and the value of reviews. When you make things easier, do you actually just make things harder? No matter what you're doing, there will always be a better way. Just keep in mind, it’s not about the length of your to-do list, it’s about the quality. You've just been Jevons'd.*

attributes.title: [Ep223] Hot Dog Bait and Switch
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Salutations, Shenanites! This week, we talk about actually fun baseball, the paralysis of choice, and middling feelings. attributes.title: [Ep215] Three Hour Buckets
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about virtual nightsoil, suit up preparations, and corner multiplicity. Then we get really honest about that wily entity called time--why is there never enough? Plus, we had quarterly reviews last week, and things have totally flown off the rails! Wanna hear how? Pull up a coffee and take a listen.
attributes.description:
Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about virtual nightsoil, suit up preparations, and corner multiplicity. Then we get really honest about that wily entity called time--why is there never enough? Plus, we had quarterly reviews last week, and things have totally flown off the rails! Wanna hear how? Pull up a coffee and take a listen.

Ever wanted to catch a peek of our long lost game ScuffleBuddies? Sounds like you should come to the second annual Bscotch Shenanicon! More info at https://meet.bscotch.net -- spots are limited, so snag your ticket ASAP!

Questions answered (abbreviated):

  • BscotchChristine: Before, you guys mentioned on wanting to be an entertainment studio. Is that still the goal or has it shifted to be solely focused on games?
  • ANGRY MUFFIN: What was your favorite part of the Shenanicon last year? What part did you look back and think, we could/should have DEFINITELY NOT done that part?
  • Drell: Recently I started a 9-5 gamedev job, and when the ShenaniJam started, I was too tired to participate. How do you guys have the energy to do all of the extra things you do? Especially when they are related to what you do for a living?
  • Zivix: What will you guys do if the podcast questions page ever runs out of questions? Karaoke segment?
  • Beekie Boppaboop: How well can you estimate how long a feature will take to build? Do you have any tips on how to do that?

attributes.title: [Ep214] Butterscotch ShenaniJam 2019 LIVE Kick-down!
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: We survived, Shenanites, and so did you! In this live kick-down event, we talk about our newest goop installment, and hear about some of YOUR experiences too! attributes.title: [Ep212] Disagreement Glaciers
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hey, hey, Shenanites! This week, we talk about sulfurous egg water, hitbox bullshit, and push-up monsters. Then we get philosophical in our in-depth discussion about chairs. If you put a chair on your head, does it become a hat? Or are you just a weirdo with a chair on your head? Agree to disagree.
attributes.description:

If you put a chair on your head, does it become a hat? Or are you just a weirdo with a chair on your head? Agree to disagree.

The Shenanijam is THIS VERY WEEKEND! Come join us, and watch us break the golden rule of jamming. Go to https://shenanijam.com for more details and to sign up!

attributes.title: [Ep211] The Mongers You Know
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hi, Shenanites! In this episode, we discuss head to toe calluses, a demo journey, and the great wishlist purge of 2019. Plus, some news on spooky stones and necessary evils. Wouldn’t your day just be better if the internet was filled with infinite kittens? (Built-in razors not included.) Better find yourself a specialized monger for that.

attributes.title: [Ep210] Twenty Shirt Trap
attributes.author: Butterscotch Shenanigans
attributes.summary: Hello, Shenanites! This week, we talk about over optimistic carry, moving bottlenecks, and itchy demos. In the tech tree of life, you gotta unlock reading before you can do anything else. Also, volumes are hard, especially if you’re trying to estimate how many animals you’ve eaten. Do Seth a favor: at the end of your long work day, have a nice mug of wine (if you’re of legal drinking age, of course). It’s the most superior drinking vessel.
